awd_titl_txt: ARI-MA: Dissuading Adversaries and their RN Pathways: Integrating Deterrence Theory and Analytics in the GNDA
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed multidisciplinary project will analyze the deterrent and deflective effects of a range of potential defensive investments in the Global Nuclear detection Architecture (GNDA) on adversary behaviors. Using a Stackelberg game-theoretical model in which the defender and adversaries are embedded in a geospatial network where segments and points exert influence on both sets of actors cost-benefit analyses, the project will identify optimal investment and communication strategy equilibria that
simultaneously minimize the non-state adversary radiological or nuclear threat (risk, vulnerability and consequence) and implementation costs.  The existing models variously assess: a) adversaries? likely interest in, means of acquiring and weaponizing materials, and the success thereof; b) targeting preferences; c) weapon command and control preferences; and d) smuggling route preferences. Additional models under development expressly take into account the impact of future technological and geopolitical developments on adversary RN behavior and will also be integrated into the proposed project.  In addition to the likely practical value of this project, it will significantly advance the study of non-state adversary deterrence by exploring the effects and interactions between different types of deterrent strategies. The integration of interdisciplinary theories, game-theoretical insights, and robust real-world empiricism will greatly enhance the fundamental understanding of the dynamic interactions between non-state adversaries and the GNDA. As a result, the project will advance the understanding of deterrence within a geospatial context, the distinctions between deterrence and deflection, the second order effects of deterrent efforts on non-targeted actors, and the potential effects and effectiveness of strategic communication with non-state adversaries.  Most importantly, the proposed project will involve undergraduate students and a post-doctoral researcher, working on a multi-university, multi-disciplinary project which integrates rigorous theoretical development with practitioner-oriented outcomes.

por.por_cntn:
This multidisciplinary project was the first phase of a five year effort co-funded by the National Science Foundation and the Academic Research Initiative at the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office in order to improve and integrate several of START’s previous data collection and modeling efforts to better understand potential radiological or nuclear (RN) adversary behaviors. These are being combined into a single, comprehensive model in order to allow analysis of the deterrent and deflective effects of a range of potential defensive investments in the Global Nuclear Detection Architecture (GNDA). The project uses cutting-edge criminological and political science non-state actor deterrence theory and game-theoretical approaches to combine these previous models, which themselves draw on deep qualitative and contextual empirical data on violent non-state actors. These insights help to identify the likely effects of a range of policies to prevent adversaries from accessing, acquiring, weaponizing and/or using RN weapons on specific targets. Given the commitment level of some adversaries to pursuing such weapons, this project focuses heavily on their potential shifts in behavior to pursue different sources, weapons, targets, routes and potential partners.

The first phase of the project consisted of seven distinct efforts that were integrated into an overarching analytical model: 1. A large literature review of criminology and political science literature; 2. A Stackelberg game-theoretical model of adversary-defender dynamic decisionmaking; 3. Detailed adversary profiles and data; 4. A comparative RN smuggling threat assessment; 5. A Monte Carlo behavioral model of adversary weapon, target, and use outcomes; 6. A smuggling route optimization tool (TransIT); and 7. A geospatial cost calculator for domestic attacks. These seven efforts are integrated into a game-theoretic model in which the defender and adversaries are embedded in a geospatial network where the segments and points exert influence on both actors’ cost-benefit analyses. This provides an alternative, but compatible approach to the Probabilistic Effectiveness Model (PEM), currently used by GNDA analysts seeking to incorporate the dynamic nature of the adversarial threat when developing and implementing policies and investments. Although a conceptually similar approach to PEM, this model incorporates much more sophisticated adversary behavioral models that draw on highly detailed adversary and geographic data.

The project team has presented preliminary findings to federal, state and local governmental audiences as well as academic conferences for risk analysis, international relations, and criminology. These findings (although highly preliminary) include:

  • A wide-ranging review of the extant literature finds remarkably little work done to date in the open literature on evaluating the deterrent effect of security investments on the behavior of non-state actors. As a result, most of the theoretical insights incorporated in the model relied on drawing corollaries from related subjects, which will require considerable sensitivity analysis. This situation will likely improve as the terrorism deterrence subfield continues to develop and expands beyond its early focus on “deterrence by punishment” strategies.
